title: Subject-template template schema

propertyDescriptions.subject-general-element: Metadata relating to the subject of the experiment.
propertyDescriptions.subject-training-element: Information on training of the animal.
propertyDescriptions.subject-surgery-element: Information on surgeries performed on of the animal.

items.title: subject-general-element field schema
items.description: subject-general-element field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.56

propertyDescriptions.genotypic sex: Sex of the subject being defined.
propertyDescriptions.subjectSpecies: Binomial species name from NCBI taxonomy
propertyDescriptions.subejctSpeciesStrain: String value indicating the strain of the species, for example: C57BL/6J.
propertyDescriptions.subjectSpeciesStrainRRID: Research resource identifier (RRID) of the strain of the species.
propertyDescriptions.subjectAbbreviatedID: Abbreviated identifier of the subject, for instance, identifier used in file names.
propertyDescriptions.subjectBirthDate: Birthdate of the subject, if available.
propertyDescriptions.subjectAge: Age of the participant at time of begining of recording (first data point recorded) in years.
propertyDescriptions.subjectCharacter: Remarks on the general characteristics of the subject, if any.

propertyDescriptions.in2pb-header: Header to be used for metadata templates created for In2PB projects.

in2pb-header.title: in2pb-header field schema
in2pb-header.description: in2pb-header field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.56

_ui._content:
In2PrimateBrains Metadata Template

The template here aims to allow the researchers to contribute structured metadata describing their experiments intuitively using a form-based and spreadsheet like interface. This in turns enhances the findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability (FAIR) of your contributed datasets.

This metadata template was developed based on existing data standards and minimum reporting guidelines by the research team at the Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München (LMU) and the German Neuroinformatics Node. The template was built as a part of the In2PrimateBrains Project, funded by MSCA-ITN-H2020 Grant Number 956669.

The template was built with the Center for Expanded Data Annotation and Retrieval (CEDAR) Workbench.

If you need any clarification about this form or if you're interested in contributing, please reach out to Reema Gupta (reema.gupta@lmu.de).

Tips for using this form:

  1. To see the description of the field, hover the cursor on
  2. There may be too many items in the drop-down menu for fields assigned with ontological support. Please enter the first few letters of your desired value and wait for a few seconds. The form will attempt to autocomplete your entry with standardized vocabulary.
  3. In the top-right corner, you can use the “Copy” button  to duplicate the field or element, or the “Toggle View” button  to switch to a tabular spreadsheet-like view for metadata entry. This applies to fields or elements that allow multiple entries.
  4. If the information is not available or is not applicable, leave the field blank.
  5. Use the free text field at the end of the template to provide any other additional information that you may want to convey.

propertyDescriptions.subject-header: Header with instructions for the subject metadata.

subject-header.title: subject-header field schema
subject-header.description: subject-header field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.56

_ui._content:
Subject Metadata Template

The purpose of this template is to describe the subject information for about the individual subjects (animals) for which the data was recorded. Some metadata fields here are based on the brain imaging data structure (BIDS) specifications to describe participants.

This template is further divided into 3 different sections:

  1. General Metadata:  This section is intended to provide general information about the subject such as the sex, species, identifier, etc.
  2. Training Metadata: This section is to be used if the animal was trained on a specific task before recording of the data.
  3. Surgery Metadata: This section is to be used to provide information on the surgeries done on the subject. Please consider using multiple entries in this section and the field 'surgery type' to describe all the surgeries that were performed, such as 'head post implantation,' 'array implantation,' etc.

subject-header.schema:description: Header with instructions for the subject metadata.
subject-header.schema:name: subject-header
